awd_titl_txt: Molecular Ions: an Hybrid Atom-Ion Platform to Generate Quantum States
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent developments in information technology are having a large impact on the society. One factor in the explosion of new technologies is the rapid increase in computing power, described by Moore's law: processor power doubles every 18 months. This is accompanied by a reduction in the size of the processors. In the near future, the actual processors based on classical treatment of information will reach the quantum limit; the uncertainty principle of quantum mechanics will come into play. Quantum Information Science (QIS) is a new approach to information science that takes advantage of laws of quantum mechanics. New advances in quantum information indicate that devices based on fundamental quantum principles, such as interference and entanglement, can perform certain tasks considerably more efficiently than any classical computer. Efforts in quantum information processing have led to protocols for quantum cryptography, and quantum algorithms. Many platforms have been studied for QIS, such as trapped ions, neutral atoms, Rydberg atoms, atoms in crystals, spin of particles, photons in cavity quantum electrodynamics (QED) or nonlinear optical setups, mesoscopic ensembles, and polar molecules.

As the field of quantum information science matures, so do its goals. There is a search for more realistic and better scalable systems, for novel areas of application and stronger cross-fertilization with other areas in physics. A hybrid platform for generating quantum states and for quantum information processing, based on molecular ions will be studied, with an eye towards feasibility, scalability, and connection with other subfields in physics. This hybrid platform shares the advantages of other platforms; the long coherence times of neutral atoms, and strong interactions of trapped ions. The required properties of these systems will be studied in order to identify the best candidates among molecular ions that will allow the Coulomb interactions between atoms to be switched off and on. This will help guide efforts in designing new experimental apparatus for quantum information processing.

The main effort relates to quantum information science, namely the possible generation of quantum states, and the implementation of phase gates. First, the use of molecular ions as enablers to design non-trivial states, such as non-local atoms will be explored. Specific species, alkali+alkaline earth and homonuclear alkaline earth diatomic molecular ions will be studied and their properties (energy surfaces, transition moments, hyperfine structure, etc.) computed. Second, arrays of neutral atoms and trapped ions that could be used to effectively create strong long-range interactions that can be switched on and off by using molecular ions as mediators to enable entanglement will be studied, systems, such as combinations of sodium (Na) and calcium (Ca), Na + Ca+, or Ca + Ca+. These new systems will be explored using realistic parameters from careful calculations, to help in understanding complex physical systems, and to predict new phenomena and to generate new theoretical concepts. The exploratory research on quantum computing with molecular ions promises to broaden the scope of QIS and atomic, molecular and optical physics to mesoscopic systems, and condensed matter physics.

por.por_cntn:
The rapid developments in information technology are having a major impact on the society. A key factor is the rapid increase in computing power, described by Moore?s law: processor power doubles every 18 months. This is accompanied by a reduction in the size of the processors, and in the near future, the actual processors based on classical treatment of information will reach the quantum limit; the uncertainty principle of quantum mechanics will come into play.

 

Quantum Information Science (QIS) is a new approach to information science that takes advantage of laws of quantum mechanics. Many platforms have been studied for QIS, such as trapped ions, neutral atoms, photons in cavity QED or nonlinear optical setups, or molecules, to name a few. In this research program, we investigated a hybrid platform for generating quantum states and for quantum information processing, based on molecular ions, with an eye towards feasibility, scalability, and connection with other subfields in physics. This hybrid platform shares the advantages of other platforms; the long coherence times of neutral atoms, and strong interactions of trapped ions.

 

As part of our research, we studied the formation of ultracold molecular ions, which are the basis for this new platform. In particular, we investigated how two species of atoms ?readily? cooled to ultracold temperatures could be manipulated to form a molecular ion. We focused our efforts on sodium (Na) neutral atoms and calcium ion (Ca+), forming NaCa+. The mismatch between the length scales of the interaction between Na and Ca+ and that of the molecular ion NaCa+ make it very difficult to transfer a free atom-ion pair into a specific molecular ion state; we identified laser pulse sequences optimizing the formation of NaCa+, a key ingredient of our original proposal to generate entangled states. We also explored how it could be possible to control charge transfer between two isotopes of the same element using a tool now routinely employed with neutral systems, namely magnetically tunable Feshbach resonances. In particular, we studied alkaline earth elements beryllium (Be) and calcium (Ca), with transfer between isotopes of Be and Be+, and Ca and Ca+. We found that it is possible to tune magnetic fields to value where charge transfer can be switch on or off, hence controlling the process. Having switchable interactions is a key ingredient for implementing quantum gates.

 

Since the atom-ion polarization potential are very long-range in nature, we also studied how resonances affect the scattering properties of the interacting atom-ion pairs. To that effect, we formulated a new phase-amplitude approach to compute the wave function, replacing the non-linear Milne equation by a 3rd-order linear equation. The new approach allows to obtain slowly varying functions that are also extremely accurate.

 

Finally, as an extension of our work on controlling charge transfer, we explored reactions between neutral atoms and more complicated ions, namely molecular ions. The goal was to find out if one could control the outcome of reactions. We explored the reaction Ca + BaOCH3+ giving BaOCa++ CH3. Our results, in collaboration with a experimental team from UCLA, show the reaction to occur via the excited Ca(3PJ) triplet state, and to depend on the J-value of the fine-structure. This was the first synthesis of the mixed hypermetallic oxide BaOCa+ from laser-cooled reagents in an atom-ion hybrid trap.

 

Overall, we computed the require properties and identify candidates among molecular ions that allow to effectively switch on and off Coulombs interactions between atoms. Our results will help guiding efforts in designing new experimental apparatus for quantum information processing using atoms and ions.
